The ways I make my child feel inferior are numerous, and I've honed them over time to be quite effective. First and foremost, I never miss an opportunity to criticize. Whether it's their appearance, their performance in school, or their hobbies, I always find something to pick apart. I also compare them unfavorably to their peers or even to myself when I was their age. I remind them of all the things I accomplished and how they pale in comparison. I also use fear to control them. I make them afraid of the consequences of not meeting my expectations, of making mistakes, of being independent. This fear keeps them in line and prevents them from questioning my authority or challenging my behavior.

Lastly, I make sure to withhold affection and praise. I only give them attention when they've done something that meets my approval, and even then, it's always conditional. This makes them crave my validation and approval, which I use to manipulate them into doing what I want.

These strategies, combined, are very effective in making my child feel inferior and dependent on me. It's a delicate balance, but one that I've mastered over the years.
